user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_set_initial_state_:
```c
void
MHD_connection_set_initial_state_ (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  size_t read_buf_size;

#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert ( (0 == (c->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS)) || \
               (MHD_TLS_CONN_INIT == c->tls_state) );
  mhd_assert ( (0 != (c->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS)) || \
               (MHD_TLS_CONN_NO_TLS == c->tls_state) );
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_INIT == c->state);

  c->keepalive = MHD_CONN_KEEPALIVE_UNKOWN;
  c->event_loop_info = MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_READ;

  memset (&c->rq, 0, sizeof(c->rq));
  memset (&c->rp, 0, sizeof(c->rp));

  c->write_buffer = NULL;
  c->write_buffer_size = 0;
  c->write_buffer_send_offset = 0;
  c->write_buffer_append_offset = 0;

  c->continue_message_write_offset = 0;

  c->read_buffer_offset = 0;
  read_buf_size = c->daemon->pool_size / 2;
  c->read_buffer
    = MHD_pool_allocate (c->pool,
                         read_buf_size,
                         false);
  c->read_buffer_size = read_buf_size;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no explicit use of compiler or language extensions in the provided function. Specifically:

- There are no GCC/Clang-style builtins or extensions such as __attribute__, __extension__, __asm__, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), or asm labels.
- There is no use of Microsoft-specific extensions (e.g. __declspec), no inline assembly, and no nonstandard keywords.
- The backslash characters seen are line-continuation characters (backslash-newline) used inside the mhd_assert calls; line splicing via backslash-newline is part of the C preprocessing phase in the standard and is not a compiler extension.
- Use of standard types (size_t) and boolean literal false is consistent with standard C (stdbool.h / C99).
- Standard library calls (memset) and pointer/structure member accesses are normal C.

Note: The mhd_assert and MHD_pool_allocate identifiers are macros/functions whose definitions are not included here. If those macros or functions (their definitions elsewhere in the codebase) use compiler-specific extensions, those definitions should be inspected. Based solely on the code shown, there are no language extensions present and therefore no fragments to flag for Rule 1.2.
